diagrams.name: Na/Al vs K/Al Molar Ratio Diagram (modified from Davies & Whitehead 2006)
comments: Alkali/alumina molar ratios of feldspars, micas and clay minerals.
Alunite plots at the same point as muscovite; clay minerals and other aluminous non alkali-bearing minerals such as many chlorites, epidote and topaz lie at the origin on this diagram.
references: Davies J. F. and Whitehead R. E., 2006, Alkali-alumina and MgO-alumina molar ratios of altered and unaltered rhyolites: Exploration and Mining Geology, v. 15, p. 77–90

diagrams.name: Alteration box plot
comments: Chlorite Carbonate Pyrite Index vs Alteration Index. Fe must be reported as ferrous/ferric oxides and aliased to FeO* and Fe2O3*
CCPI = 100*(MgO+(FeO+Fe2O3*0.8998122))/(MgO+Na2O+(FeO+Fe2O3*0.8998122)+K2O), AI = 100*(MgO+K2O)/MgO+Na2O+CaO+K2O)
This diagram can be used to describe hydrothermal alteration of volcanic rocks, especially in a VMS deposit setting.
Mineral names ab albite, adl adularia, il illite, chl chlorite, py pyrite, ep epidote, ca calcite, dol dolomite, ank ankerite
references: Large, R.R. et al., 2001, The alteration box plot: A simple approach to understanding the relationships between alteration mineralogy and lithogeochemistry associated with VHMS deposits
Economic Geology, vol. 96, pp. 957-971.

diagrams.name: Alteration box plot
comments: Chlorite Carbonate Pyrite Index (CCPI) vs Alteration Index (AI). Use FeO (total) or Fe2O3 (total) aliased to FeO or Fe2O3
CCPI = 100*(MgO+FeO)/(MgO+Na2O+FeO+K2O), AI = 100*(MgO+K2O)/MgO+Na2O+CaO+K2O)
This diagram can be used to describe hydrothermal alteration of volcanic rocks, especially in a VMS deposit setting.
Mineral names ab albite, adl adularia, il illite, chl chlorite, py pyrite, ep epidote, ca calcite, dol dolomite, ank ankerite
references: Large, R.R. et al., 2001, The alteration box plot: A simple approach to understanding the relationships between alteration mineralogy and lithogeochemistry associated with VHMS deposits
Economic Geology, vol. 96, pp. 957-971.

diagrams.name: Alteration Box Plot: Ishikawa Alteration Index (AI) vs Advanced Argillic Alteration Index (AAAI)
comments: Increase in AAAI represents strong SiO2 enrichment and destruction of chlorite, carbonate and feldspar. These are the mineralogical changes that are also seen in advanced argillic alteration zones in high-sulfidation epithermal systems.
The Ishikawa Alteration Index reflects the abundance of chlorite and sericite and depletion of CaO and Na2O associated with feldspar destruction.

The arrow on the plot indicates the trend from the unaltered box toward pyrophyllite alteration zones. The box for unaltered samples is defined in the advanced argillic alteration index by the spread of least altered (proplytic) samples
as defined in the source paper and in the AI by the least altered box of the Alteration Box Plot by Large et al. (2001)
references: Williams, N.C., and Davidson, G.J., 2004, Possible submarine advanced argillic alteration at the Basin Lake prospect, Western Tasmania, Australia: Economic Geology v.99, pp. 987-1002

Large, R.R. et al., 2001, The alteration box plot: A simple approach to understanding the relationship between alteration mineralogy and lithogeochemistry associated with volcanic-hosted massive sulfide deposits: Economic Geology v.96, pp. 957-972
diagrams.sourceFile: Alteration Box Plot AI vs AAAI.xml

diagrams.name: Volcanic Rock Alteration (Projected from C)
comments: Molar element ratio plot for typical fresh volcanic rocks and main alteration minerals, used to determine alteration trends.
Use weight percent oxide values. Conversion to molecular proportions is automatic. Abbreviations Kln-Kaolinite, Plg-Plagioclase Feldspar, KS-Potassic Feldspar, Ab-Albite, Bt-Biotite

The effects of Ca metasomatism (calcite) can partly mask the effects of K metasomatism. This version of the K-Ca-Na diagram is projected from CO2 (C), which removes the effects of calcite (assuming all analyzed CO2 are contained in Calcite).
references: After Warren I., Simmons S. F., and Mauk J. L., Whole-Rock Geochemical Techniques for Evaluating Hydrothermal Alteration, Mass Changes, and Compositional Gradients Associated with Epithermal Au-Ag Mineralization, Economic Geology, v.102, pp.923-948, 2007

diagrams.name: Selwyn Deposit Fe Stone Classification (CRC LEME 2002)
comments: Discriminates between barren and mineralised Fe stone in the Selwyn Au-Cu deposit in NW Queensland.
The axes of the diagram are calculated Principal Components of the following elements: Mg, K, Mn, Cu, Co, W, Ba, Au and Rb.
references: CRC LEME OFR 128. 2002. The geochemical discrimination of mineralised and barren ironstones from the Selwyn Au-Cu Deposit, N.W. Queensland.

diagrams.name: Selwyn Deposit Fe Stone Classification - No Au or Cu (CRC LEME 2002)
comments: Discriminates between barren and mineralised Fe stone in the Selwyn Au-Cu deposit in NW Queensland.
The axes of the diagram are calculated Principal Components of the following elements: Mg, K, Mn, Co, W, Ba, and Rb.
Cu and Au are omitted from the calculated Principal Components in this diagram to remove the influence of Cu and Au in differentiating between the mineralised and barren Fe rocks.
references: CRC LEME OFR 128. 2002. The geochemical discrimination of mineralised and barren ironstones from the Selwyn Au-Cu Deposit, N.W. Queensland.
diagrams.sourceFile: Selwyn Fe Stone Classification - No Cu-Au (CRC LEME, 2002).xml

diagrams.name: Cu/Pd vs Pd (Karykowski et al 2017)
comments: Used to model the PGE contents of Ni-Cu sulphide deposits and PGE-dominated deposits (reefs).
Difference between the partition coefficients for Cu and Pd into sulphide liquid allows the use of the Cu/Pd ratio with most PGE-rich samples showing lower Cu/Pd ratios.
Red lines represent model sulphides crystallising from a slightly metal-depleted picritic melt (removal of 0.002% sulphides) at R factors ranging from 1000 to 100,000.

Percentages along the red lines indicate the composition of rocks containing 0.1, 1, 10 and 100% sulphide. Blue line calculated on changes in Cu/Pd ratio and Pd contents of a silicate magma as sulphides are removed.
Modified from Barnes et al, 1993 Cu/Pd vs Pd diagram.
references: Karykowski, B.T. et al., 2017, New insights into the petrogenesis of the Jameson Range layered intrusion and associated Fe-Ti-P-V-PGE-Au mineralisation, West Musgrave Province, Western Australia
Miner Deposita, vol. 52, pp. 233-255.
Barnes, S.J. et al., 1993, Nickel-Copper Occurences in the Belleterre-Angliers Belt of the Pontiac Subprovince and the Use of Cu-Pd Ratios in Interpreting Platinum-Group Element Distributions.
Economic Geology, vol.88, pp. 1402-1418

Diagram should not be used for samples with less than 300ppm Cu and over 3000ppm Ni
references: Clema J.M., and Stevens-Oare N.P., 1973. A method for distinguishing nickel gossans from other ironstones on the Yilgarn Shield, Western Australia. J. Geochem. Explor., 2:393-402

diagrams.name: Porphyry Cu Prospectivity (La/Sm)n vs (Dy/Yb)n

diagrams.name: Sr/Y vs SiO2
comments: Two fields represent i) rock suites associated with Cu-Au ore deposits and ii) a barren reference rock suite defined by samples from NW Pacific volcanic arcs, including intraoceanic and continental margin arcs (Kurile Arc, N. Honshu Arc, Central Ryukyu and Izu-Bonin Arc).
All analyses are from fresh or weakly altered (weakly propylitic at most) whole-rock samples.
references: Diagram from Cohen et al. (2010) after Rohrlach, B.D. and Loucks, R.R. (2005).
Cohen et al., 2010. Major advances in exploration geochemistry, 1998-2007. Geochemistry: Exploration, Environment, Analysis, vol. 10, pp. 3-16

Rohrlach, B.D. and Loucks, R.R. 2005. Multi-million-year cyclic ramp-up of volatiles in a lower crustal magma reservoir trapped below the Tampakan copper-gold deposit by Mio-Pliocene crustal compression in the southern Philippines.
In: PORTER, T.M. (ed.) Super porphyry copper and gold deposits. A global perspective. PGC Publishing, Perth, vol. 2, 270p.
diagrams.sourceFile: Sr-Y v SiO2 (Cohen et al, 2010 mod after Rohrlach & Loucks, 2005).xml

diagrams.name: Sr/Y vs SiO2 wt%
comments: Ratio Sr/Y usually effective in discriminating Cu ore-forming magmas from ordinary andesites, dacites and rhyolites in
apparently unmineralised arc segments around the pacific margin. For prospectivity assessments of igneous complexes, sites
having Sr/Y>35 at SiO2>57 wt% can be regarded as Cu-fertile.
references: Loucks, R.R., 2014, Distinctive composition of copper ore-forming arc magmas: Australian Journal of Earth Sciences, v. 61, pp. 5-16.

comments: This diagram uses Cu and S data in ppm to classify copper sulphide mineralogy.
Cc = Chalcocite, Bn = Bornite, Cpy = Chalcopyrite,  Py = Pyrite
Mineral field boundaries are defined as halfway between atomic weight ratios of Cu and S in copper sulphide minerals end member.
references: In-house, REFLEX Geochemistry 2012

diagrams.name: Fe Oxide - Quartz - Kaolinite Plot
comments: This diagram uses SiO2 and Fe data (in pct) to assess mineralogical controls on iron ore grade.
Used to classify the various types of Fe ore based on Fe and clay content.
Qtz = Quartz, Kln = Kaolinite, Other (any other mineral with no Si or Fe present, e.g. Dolomite), Goe = Goethite, Hem = Hematite
references: In-house classification diagram produced by REFLEX Geochemistry, 2014.

diagrams.name: Phyllite Ferruginisation Stages (Jeffcoate et al 2013)
comments: Stage 3: Ferruginisation of kaolinite-rich phyllite, as reflected in increase in Fe and decrease in Al2O3.
Stage 4b: Ferruginisation of the Gibbsite rich near surface material.
Refer also to Phyllite Weathering Stages plot (Figure 6a, Jeffcoate et al. 2013) for additional information.
references: Figure 6e, Jeffcoate et al. 2013. Modelling intact rock strength of clay-rich rocks with geochemistry at the Simandou iron ore deposit, Guinea, West Africa. Iron Ore Conference, Perth, WA.

diagrams.name: Phyllite Weathering Stages (Jeffcoate et al 2013)
comments: Stage 1: Initial modification of mica to clay minerals such as kaolinite and illite.
Stage 2: Increase in clay content (in kaolinite), lowered SiO2 and increased Al2O3.
Following this, Stage 3 occurs at depth and in proximity to mineralisation or Stage 4 at/close to the surface.
Stage 3: Ferrugenisation of dominantly kaolinitic phyllites, associated with a reduction in Al2O3 and SiO2.
Stage 4a: Bauxitisation of kaolinite-dominant phyllite through prolonged leaching of silica and increase in Al2O3.
Stage 4b: Bauxitised material is modified by ferrugenisation, which is associated with a reduction in Al2O3.
references: Figure 6a, Jeffcoate et al., 2013. Modelling intact rock strength of clay-rich rocks with geochemistry at the Simandou iron ore deposit, Guinea, West Africa. Iron Ore Conference, Perth, WA.

diagrams.name: Rock Strength of Clay-Rich Rocks (Jeffcoate et al 2013)
comments: Diagram consists of Al2O3 and SiO2 on either axes.
The diagram is divided into sub-domains of Intact Rock Strength classes based on correlation with geochemical data.
The domains are based on interpretation of geochemical data from phyllite-rich rocks in around the Simandou Iron ore Deposit (Jeffcott et al. 2013)
There are four grades of Intact Rock Strength domains: R0, R1, R2 and R3 - these grades from soil and soil-like phyllite material to strong phyllite material.
references: Jeffcoate et al., 2013. Modelling Intact Rock Strength of Clay-Rich Rocks with Geochemistry at  the Simandou Iron Ore Deposit, Guinea, West Africa. Iron Ore 2013
diagrams.sourceFile: Rock Strength of Clay-Rich Rocks (Jeffcoate et al, 2013) .xml

diagrams.name: Cr2O3 vs MgO in Chromites
comments: Chromite discrimination diagram showing the field of diamond inclusions and intergrowth.
references: Diagram after Skinner et al., Lithos 76 (2004) p 233-259

diagrams.name: Cr2O3 vs TiO2 in Chromites
comments: Chromite discrimination diagram showing the field of diamond inclusions and intergrowth.
references: Diagram after Skinner et al., Lithos 76 (2004) p 233-259

diagrams.name: Diamond Al-Cr-Na
comments: KIM (Kimberlite Indicator Minerals) diagram used to discriminate mantle xenolith Cr-diopside from those of other sources
Overlapping data should be filtered out by the Na2O vs Ca/(Ca+Mg) diagram
references: Crabtree D., An overview of the Ontario Geological Survey's KIM database: Interpretation of Chromite and Cr-diopside Data from Regional Surveys
Indicator mineral methods in mineral exploration Proceedings of a short course presented by:Prospectors and developers Association of Canada, March 2003, Toronto, Canada

diagrams.name: Na2O vs Ca/(Ca+Mg)
comments: Diagram is used to discriminate Cr-diopsides in xenocrysts and xenoliths in kimberlites from those of other sources
references: Crabtree D., An overview of the Ontario Geological Survey's KIM database: Interpretation of Chromite and Cr-diopside Data from Regional Surveys
Indicator mineral methods in mineral exploration Proceedings of a short course presented by:Prospectors and developers Association of Canada, March 2003, Toronto, Canada

diagrams.name: Cr2O3 vs CaO of garnet inclusions in diamonds
comments: This classification applies to samples with less than 4% TiO2(wt%)
references: Diagram after Grutter et al., 2003, Lithos 77 (2004) p841-857
Graphite-diamond constraint (GDC) -  after Grutter et al., 2006, Jour Pet 47, 4, p801-820

diagrams.name: Garnet G#, Hi TiO2
comments: Cr2O3 vs CaO wt pct classification applies to samples with more than 4wt% TiO2
references: Diagram after Grutter et al., 2003, Lithos 77 (2004) p841-857
Graphite-diamond constraint (GDC) -  after Grutter et al., 2006, Jour Pet 47, 801-820, assumed pressure 43kbar

diagrams.name: Garnet G#, Lo TiO2
comments: Cr2O3 vs CaO, wt pct classification applies to samples with less than 4% TiO2(wt%)
references: Diagram after Grutter et al., 2003, Lithos 77 (2004) p841-857
Graphite-diamond constraint (GDC) -  after Grutter et al., 2006, Jour Pet 47, 801-820, assumed pressure 43kbar

diagrams.name: Garnet TiO2 vs Cr2O3
comments: Discrimination diagram used to separate Cr-poor garnet megacrysts from garnets in peridotites
references: Diagram after Schultze D. J., 1999 Explor. Mining Geol., Vol. 6, No. 4, pp. 349-366, 1997
diagrams.sourceFile: TiO2 vs Cr2O3 in Cr-poor garnets.xml

diagrams.name: Garnet TiO2 vs Mg#
comments: Diagram is used to separate hi TiO2 (megacrystic) from low TiO2 garnets (eclogite, pyroxenite)
Mg# is calculated as molecular. Fe must be reported as ferrous/ferric oxides and aliased to FeO* and Fe2O3*
This decides whether Hi TiO2 G# diagram or Low TiO2 G# diagram should be used to further classify the garnets
references: Diagram after Grutter et al., Lithos 77 (2004) 841-857

diagrams.name: Garnet TiO2 vs Mg#
comments: Diagram is used to separate hi TiO2 (megacrystic) from low TiO2 garnets (eclogite, pyroxenite)
Mg# is calculated as molecular. Use FeO (total) or Fe2O3 (total) aliased to FeO or Fe2O3
This decides whether Hi TiO2 G# diagram or Low TiO2 G# diagram should be used to further classify the garnets
references: Diagram after Grutter et al., Lithos 77 (2004) 841-857

diagrams.name: Garnet TiO2 vs Na2O
comments: Discrimination diagram used to separate Cr-poor garnet megacrysts from garnets found in diamondiferous eclogites
M=megacryst field, DE=diamond eclogite field, G11 field of hi-TiO2 peridotitic (Ti-metasomatised peridotite)
references: Diagram after Schultze D. J., 1999 Explor. Mining Geol., Vol. 6, No. 4, pp. 349-366, 1997

diagrams.name: Cr2O3 vs MgO for kimberlitic ilmenites
comments: Kimberlitic ilmenite discrimination diagram (between 5 and 10wt% MgO)
references: Diagram after Skinner et al., Lithos 76 (2004) 233-259

diagrams.name: Iron Oxide CaAlMn vs TiV (Dupuis and Beaudoin 2011)
comments: Ca + Al + Mn vs. Ti + V discriminant diagram for average Fe-oxide compositions from Kiruna, IOCG, porphyry Cu, skarn, Fe-Ti-V, and BIF deposits
This plot is to be used with mineral chemistry data. Whole rock chemistry data will mostly plot outside the range of values represented by the polygons in this diagram.
references: Fig. 6., Dupuis and Beaudoin, 2011. Discriminant diagrams for iron oxide trace element fingerprinting of mineral deposit types. Mineralium Deposita vol. 46, pp. 319-335
diagrams.sourceFile: Iron Oxide Ca+Al+Mn vs Ti+V (Dupuis & Beaudoin, 2011).xml

diagrams.name: Gold Solubility in Pyrite
comments: Ratios converted to ppm and drawn from...
references: Reich, M., Kesler, S.E., Utsunomiya, S., Palenik, C.S., Chryssoulis, S.L., and Ewing, R.C.; 2005, Solubility of Gold in Arsenian Pyrite, Geochimica and Cosmochimica Acta, v.69, p.2781-2786
diagrams.sourceFile: Au Solubility in Pyrite (Reich et al, 2005).xml

diagrams.name: Olivine Control Diagram
comments: Pearce Element Ratio diagram for describing olivine fractionation and/or sorting.
"Olivine" olivine control line FeO is total Fe expressed as Fe2+
references: Barnes S.J., Hill R.E.T., Perring C.S., Dowling S.E., Lithological exploration for komatiite-associated Ni-sulphide deposits: strategies and limitations
Mineralogy and petrology (2004) 82:259-293

diagrams.name: Albite Alteration GER Diagram
comments: Fig 14. GER diagram (Na+K)/Al v Na/Al showing alteration of albite to muscovite and to chlorite.
"Chl" Chlorite, "Mu" Muscovite, "KF" K-Feldspar, "Ab" Albite nodes
Axes are molar ratios.
references: Stanley, C.R. 2017. Molar Element Ratio Analysis of Lithogeochemical Data: A Toolbox for Use in Mineral Exploration and Mining, Exploration 2017:
Integrating the Geosciences: the Challenge of Discovery. Decennial Mineral Exploration Conference. Toronto, Oct. Paper 33, pp. 471-494.

diagrams.name: Alkali Feldspar Alteration GER Diagram
comments: Fig 17. GER (Na+K)/Al v Si/Al diagram describing alteration of alkali feldspar to muscovite and chlorite.
"Chl" Chlorite, "Mu" Muscovite, "AF" Alkali Feldspar nodes
Axes are molar ratios.
references: Stanley, C.R. 2017. Molar Element Ratio Analysis of Lithogeochemical Data: A Toolbox for Use in Mineral Exploration and Mining, Exploration 2017:
Integrating the Geosciences: the Challenge of Discovery. Decennial Mineral Exploration Conference. Toronto, Oct. Paper 33, pp. 471-494.

diagrams.name: Feldspar Na-K GER Diagram
comments: Molar ratios used throughout the PER-GER ratio diagrams
"KF" orthoclase,"Mu" muscovite,"Ab" albite, "Crd" cordierite, "AF" Alkali feldspar control line
references: Stanley C. R., and Madeisky H. E., 1996 Lithogeochemical Exploration for Metasomatic Zones Associated with Hydrothermal Mineral Deposits Using Pearce Element Ratio Analysis

diagrams.name: Hydration and Carbonation of Ultramafic Rocks
comments: This molar diagram describes the alteration of olivine in ultramafic rocks.

diagrams.name: IUGS Carbonatite Rock Classification
comments: Chemical classification of carbonatites using weight percent oxides of MgO, CaO, FeO, Fe2O3 and MnO.
Use when rock contains more than 50% modal carbonates.
This diagram requires the following columns to be aliased: CaO_pct, MgO_pct, FeO_pct, Fe2O3_pct, MnO_pct
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Classification of Gabbroic Rocks Plag-Px-Hbl
comments: Classification and nomenclature of gabbroic rocks based on the modal proportions of hornblende (Hbl), pyroxene (Px) and plagioclase (Plag)
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Plag, Px and Hbl.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Classification of Gabbroic Rocks Plag-Px-Ol
comments: Classification and nomenclature of gabbroic rocks based on the modal proportions of olivine (Ol), pyroxene (Px) and plagioclase (Plag)
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Plag, Px and Ol.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Melilitic Rock Classification (Plutonic)
comments: IUGS classification of melilitic plutonic rocks based on the modal proportions of Olivine (Ol), Melilite (Mel) and Clinopyroxene (Cpx).
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Mel, Ol and Cpx.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Melilitic Rock Classification (Volcanic)
comments: IUGS classification of melilitic volcanic rocks based on the modal proportions of Olivine (Ol), Melilite (Mel) and Clinopyroxene (Cpx).
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Mel, Ol and Cpx.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Classification of Pyroclastic Rocks
comments: Use classification if rock considered to have pyroclastic origin.
Bombs = pyroclasts > 64 mm with surface indicating wholly or partly molten during formation and transport. Blocks = pyroclasts >64 mm with angular/subangular surface.
Lapilli = pyroclasts of any shape between 2-64 mm in mean diameter, Ash = pyroclasts <2 mm in mean diameter.
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Blocks and Bombs, Lapilli and Ash.
references: Schmid, R., 1981. Descriptive nomenclature and classification of pyroclastic deposits and fragments:
Recommendations of the International Union of Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Geology.
The Geological Society of America. Boulder. Vol. 9, p. 41-43.

diagrams.name: IUGS Plutonic Rock Classification QAP
comments: Classification and nomenclature of plutonic rocks according to their modal mineral contents Quartz (Qtz), Alkali-Feldspar (AlkFeld) and Plagioclase (Plag)
Use when mafic minerals are <90% and re-calculate modal amounts so Qtz + AlkFeld + Plag = 100%
Column headers in data file must match diagram variables: Qtz, AlkFeld and Plag.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Volcanic Rock Classification QAP
comments: Classification and nomenclature of volcanic rocks according to their modal mineral contents Quartz (Qtz), Alkali-Feldspar (AlkFeld) and Plagioclase (Plag)
Use when mafic minerals are <90% and re-calculate modal amounts so Qtz + AlkFeld + Plag = 100%
Column headers in data file must match diagram variables: Qtz, AlkFeld and Plag.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Ultramafic Rock Classification Ol-Opx-Cpx
comments: Classification and nomenclature of ultramafic rocks (M >90%) based on the modal proportions of olivine (Ol), orthopyroxene (Opx) and clinopyroxene (Cpx).
M = mafic and related minerals (micas, amphiboles, pyroxenes, olivines, opaque minerals, epidote, allanite, garnets, melilites, monticellite, etc)
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Ol, Opx and Cpx.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: IUGS Ultramafic Rock Classification Ol-Px-Hbl
comments: Classification and nomenclature of ultramafic rocks (M >90%) based on the modal proportions of olivine (Ol), pyroxene (Px) and hornblende (Hbl).
M = mafic and related minerals (micas, amphiboles, pyroxenes, olivines, opaque minerals, epidote, allanite, garnets, melilites, monticellite, etc)
Column headers in data file must exactly match diagram variables: Ol, Px and Hbl.
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (editor), Bateman, P., Dudek, A., Keller, J. et al. 1989
A Classification of Igneous rocks and Glossary of Terms: Recommendations of the International Union of
Geological Sciences Subcommission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Blackwell Scientific Publications, Oxford.

diagrams.name: AFM Diagram FeO*
comments: Fe must be reported as ferrous/ferric oxides and aliased to FeO* and Fe2O3*, diagram is in wt%
references: Curves after Irvine and Baragar (blue), 1971 and Kuno (red), 1968

diagrams.name: AFM Diagram
comments: Alkali-iron-magnesium diagram for files with Fe reported either as FeO or Fe2O3 (wt%) or just as Fe (ppm), diagram uses wt%
references: Curves after Irvine and Baragar (blue), 1971 and Kuno (red), 1968. Rollinson, 1993, Using Geochemical Data, p75-76

diagrams.name: Alkalinity Index vs SiO2 (Frost and Frost, 2008)
comments: Distinguish between metaluminous and peralkaline feldspathic igneous rocks.
Alkalinity Index = Al/(Na+K) molar
references: Frost, B.R. and Frost, C.D., 2008, A geochemical classification for feldspathic igneous rocks.  Journal of Petrology, v. 49, p. 1955-1969.

diagrams.name: Alumina Saturation in Igneous Rocks
comments: Alumina saturation in igneous rocks
references: Barton, M.D. and Young, S., 2002, Non-pegmatitic deposits of beryllium: mineralogy, geology, phase equilibria and origin in E.S. Grew, ed., Beryllium: Mineralogy, Petrology and Geochemistry: Reviews in Mineralogy and Geochemistry, v. 50, p. 591-691.

diagrams.name: Aluminum Saturation Index vs SiO2 (Frost and Frost, 2008)
comments: Distinguish between metaluminous and peraluminous feldspathic igneous rocks
Aluminum Saturation Index (ASI) = Al/(Ca-1.67*P+Na+K) molar
references: Frost, B.R. and Frost, C.D., 2008, A geochemical classification for feldspathic igneous rocks.  Journal of Petrology, v. 49, p. 1955-1969.
diagrams.sourceFile: Aluminum Saturation Index vs SiO2 (Frost & Frost, 2008).xml

diagrams.name: Andesite types Gill 1980 K2O vs SiO2
comments: Andesite classification diagram
references: Gill J. B. 1981. Orogenic Andesites and Plate Tectonics

diagrams.name: Basaltic Andesites and Basalts of Oceanic Regions (Mullen 1983)
comments: Discriminates between five petrotectonic environments based on analyses of 507 basaltic rocks (45-54% SiO2).
Mid-ocean Ridge Basalt (MORB), Island Arc Tholeiite (IAT), Island Arc Calc-Alkaline (CAB), Seamount Tholeiite (OIT), Seamount Alkalic (OIA). Boninites plot within island arc field.
references: Mullen, E.D. 1983. MnO/TiO2/P2O5: a minor element discriminant for basaltic rocks of oceanic environments and its implications for petrogenesis. Earth and Planetary Science Letters, vol. 62, pp. 53-62.
diagrams.sourceFile: Basaltic Andesites & Basalts of Oceanic Regions (Mullen, 1983).xml

diagrams.name: Jensen Cation Plot
comments: Classification scheme for subalkaline volcanics using cation % particularly useful for komatiites
Fe must be reported as ferrous/ferric oxides and aliased to FeO* and Fe2O3*
references: Jensen, 1976 from Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 63.

diagrams.name: Jensen Cation Plot
comments: Classification scheme for subalkaline volcanics using cation % particularly useful for komatiites
Use Fe2O3 (total) aliased to Fe2O3
references: Jensen, 1976 from Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 63.

diagrams.name: Si vs Fe Ratio (Tappe et al 2006)
comments: This classification diagram differentiates between rocks that are geochemically characterised as Kimberlite, Orangeite and Aillikites (Ultramafic Lamprophyre)
references: Tappe, S., Foley, S. F., Jenner, G. A., Heaman, L. M.,Kjarsgaard, B. A., Romer, R. L., Stracke, A., Joyce, N. & Hoefs, J.(2006). Genesis of ultramafic lamprophyres and carbonatites at Aillik Bay,
Labrador: a consequence of incipient lithospheric thinning beneath the North Atlantic Craton. Journal of Petrology 47(7), pp. 1261-1315
diagrams.sourceFile: Kimberlite Si vs Fe Ratio  (Tappe et al, 2006).xml

diagrams.name: SiO2 vs Peralkalinity Index (Eccles et al 2004)
comments: This classification diagram differentiates between rocks that are geochemically characterised as Kimberlite, Orangeite, Lamproite and Minette.
references: Eccles, D.R., Luth, R.W., Heaman, L.M. and Creaser, R.A. (2004): Petrogenesis of the Late Cretaceous Northern Alberta Kimberlite Province, 8th International Kimberlite Conference, Volume Proceedings; Lithos, v. 76, pp. 435-461.
diagrams.sourceFile: Kimberlite SiO2 vs Peralkalinity Index (Eccles et al, 2004).xml

diagrams.name: Plutonic Rock Classification (Debon and Le Fort, 1983)
comments: Diagram axes correspond to proportions of K-Feldspar and Plagioclase to Quartz. P is calculated from (K - (Na+Ca)), and Q is calculated from ((Si/3) - (K+Na+(2*Ca)/3)). Parameters calculated as oxide percentages converted to millications.
references: Debon, F. & Le Fort, P. (1983). A chemical and mineralogical classification of common plutonic rocks and associations. Transactions of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, Earth Sciences 73, pp. 135-149
diagrams.sourceFile: Plutonic Rock Classification (Debon and Le Fort, 1983).xml

diagrams.name: Provenance Signatures (mod after Roser and Korsch 1988)
comments: Discriminant function analysis using Al2O3, TiO2, Fe2O3T, MgO, CaO, Na2O and K2O.
Plotting these discriminant functions effectively separates between four differing provenance groups
: Felsic, quartzitic, mafic and intermediate provenances.
Fe is Fe total. Equation is written so all Fe is converted to Fe2O3. If having Fe as Fe2O3 (total) no conversion is needed, just use 0.76*Fe2O3
Diagram is modified after Roser and Korsch (1988). Na is not used in the discriminant function analysis.
references: Roser, B.P. and Korsch, R.J. 1988 provenance signatures of sandstone-mudstone suites determined
using discriminant function analysis of major-element data. Chem. Geol. 67: 119-139

diagrams.name: Provenance Signatures (Roser and Korsch 1988
comments: Discriminant function analysis using Al2O3, TiO2, Fe2O3T, MgO, CaO, Na2O and K2O.
Plotting these discriminant functions effectively separates between four differing provenance groups
: Felsic, quartzitic, mafic and intermediate provenances.
Fe is Fe total. Equation is written so all Fe is converted to Fe2O3. If having Fe as Fe2O3 (total) no conversion is needed, just use 0.76*Fe2O3
references: Roser, B.P. and Korsch, R.J. 1988 provenance signatures of sandstone-mudstone suites determined
using discriminant function analysis of major-element data. Chem. Geol. 67: 119-139

diagrams.name: R1-R2 Plutonic Chemical Variation Diagram
comments: Chemical variation diagram which includes major cations, mineralogical network, degree of silica saturation and combined changes in Fe/(Fe+Mg) and (Ab+Or)/An ratios in plutonic igneous rocks. Use FeO (total) or Fe2O3 (total) aliased to FeO or Fe2O3
R1 = 4Si-11(Na+K)-2(Fe+Ti) R2 = 6Ca+2Mg+Al. Parameters calculated as oxide percentages converted to millications.
references: De la Roche et al, 1980. A classification of volcanic and plutonic rocks using R1 R2 diagram and major element analyses - Its relationships with current nomenclature. Chem. Geol., 29: 183-210

diagrams.name: R1-R2 Volcanic Chemical Variation Diagram
comments: Chemical variation diagram which includes major cations, mineralogical network, degree of silica saturation and combined changes in Fe/(Fe+Mg) and (Ab+Or)/An ratios in volcanic igneous rocks. Use FeO (total) or Fe2O3 (total) aliased to FeO or Fe2O3
R1 = 4Si-11(Na+K)-2(Fe+Ti) R2 = 6Ca+2Mg+Al. Parameters calculated as oxide percentages converted to millications.
references: De la Roche et al, 1980. A classification of volcanic and plutonic rocks using R1 R2 diagram and major element analyses - Its relationships with current nomenclature. Chem. Geol., 29: 183-210

diagrams.name: Terrigenous Shales and Sandstones (Herron 1988)
comments: Three chemical parameters (SiO2/Al2O3 ratio, Fe2O3/K2O ratio and Ca content) used to differentiate between sandstone and shale
Total iron (Fe2O3T) is used
references: Herron, M. M., 1988 Geochemical classification of terrigenous sands and shales from core or log data. J. Sed. Petrol. 58, 820-829.

diagrams.name: TAS Plutonic (Middlemost 1994)
comments: Total alkalis versus silica (Na2+K2O vs SiO2) general igneous rocks classification diagram
references: Middlemost, E.A.K., 1994, Naming materials in the magma/igneous rock system; Earth-Science Reviews, v. 37, pp. 215-224

diagrams.name: TAS Plutonic (Cox et al. 1979 adapted by Wilson 1989)
comments: Chemical classification and nomenclature of plutonic rocks using the total alkali vs silica. The curved solid line subdivides the alkaic from subalkaic rocks.
references: Cox et al., 1979, adapted by Wilson., 1989, in Rollinson, Using Geochemical Data, 1993, p.52.
Cox, K. G., Bell, J. D. and Pankhurst, R. J. (1979). The Interpretation of Igneous Rocks. George Allen and Unwin.
diagrams.sourceFile: TAS Plutonic (Mod after Cox et al 1979).xml

diagrams.name: TAS Classification Diagram
comments: Total alkalis versus silica (Na2+K2O vs SiO2) general igneous rocks classification diagram
references: Le Maitre, R. W. (1989). A Classification of Igneous Rocks and Glossary of Terms. Recommendations of the IUGS Commission on the Systematics of Igneous Rocks. Oxford: Blackwell.

Derived from work done in Le Bas, M. J., Le Maitre, R. W., Streckeisen, A. and Zanettin, B. (1986). A chemical classification of volcanic rocks based on the total alkali-silica diagram. Journal of Petrology 27, 745-750.

diagrams.name: Alkaline/Subalkaline Classification Diagram
comments: Volcanic Alkaline-Subalkaline classification in Na2O+K2O vs SiO2 space
references: Curve after Irvine and Baragar, 1971. Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 53

diagrams.name: Subdivision of Subalkalic Rocks using K2O vs SiO2
comments: Subdivisions of Le Maitre et al. (1989) - red lines with nomenclature in red and of Rickwood (1989) - nomenclature in parentheses
Shaded bands are the fields in which fall the boundary lines of Peccerillo and Taylor (1976), Ewart (1982), Innocenti et al. (1982), Carr (1985) and Middlemost (1985) as summarised by Rickwood (1989)
references: Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Fig. 3.5 Page 56.
diagrams.sourceFile: Volcanic K2O vs SiO2 Subalkalic Subdivisions (Various).xml

diagrams.name: Regolith Classification (McQueen 2006)
comments: Three types of regolith from Cobar, NSW are used to define the saprolite, clays and younger alluvium and colluvium fields
references: McQueen K.G., 2006. Unravelling the regolith with geochemistry. In Fitzpatrick R.W. and Shand P. (Eds) Regolith 2006-Consolidation and Dispersion of Ideas, CRC LEME, Perth Western Australia, pp230-235

diagrams.name: Ti vs Zr (Hallberg 1984)
comments: Volcanic rock classification in deeply weathered terrain using conserved elements Ti and Zr.
references: Hallberg, J. A., 1984, A geochemical aid to igneous rock type identification in deeply weathered terrain. Journal of Geochemical Exploration, 20: 1-8

diagrams.name: Zr-Al2O3-TiO2 Weathered Rock Type
comments: This diagram contains observed range of composition for strongly peraluminous granites and clastic sediments and illustrates the geometrical relationship between sedimentary and plutonic composition trends.

references: Sedimentary Fractionations between Al, Ti, and Zr and the genesis of strongly peraluminous granites, Garcia et al. 1994, The Journal of Geology, 1994, v. 102, p 411-422 Fig 9.

diagrams.name: Basalt Th-Hf-Ta (Wood 1980)
comments: Basalt discrimination diagram based on HFS
If Hf and Ta are not analysed use diagram WOOD Th-Zr-Nb
WPT = Within Plate Tholeiites, VAB = Volcanic Arc Basalts, IAT = Island Arc Tholeiites, CAB = Calk-Alkaline Basalts, WPB = Within Plate Basalts
references: From Wood (1980), found in Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 182-185.

diagrams.name: Basalt Th/Yb vs Nb/Yb (Pearce 2008)
comments: Fig 2a. Basalt classification diagram with Th-Nb as proxy for crustal input, divided into oceanic basalts and volcanic arc basalts field.
Acronyms: MORB - Mid-Oceanic Ridge Basalt, OIB - Ocean-Island Basalt, N-MORB - Normal-MORB, E-MORB - Plume-MORB. N-MORB is depleted in trace elements compared to E-MORB.
references: Pearce, J.A. 2008. Geochemical fingerprinting of oceanic basalts with applications to ophiolite classification and the search for Archean oceanic crust, Lithos. vol. 100, pp. 14-48

diagrams.name: Basalt Th/Yb vs Nb/Yb (Pearce 2014)
comments: Fig 5A. derived from Pearce (2008) version of the Th/Yb vs Nb/Yb diagram, lavas from non-subduction settings plot along a MORB-OIB array.
Lavas modified from subduction-related settings plot above the MORB-OIB array as the immobility of Th in subductions settings results in higher Th/Yb ratios.
MORB - Mid-Oceanic Ridge Basalt, OIB - Ocean-Island Basalt, N-MORB - Normal-MORB, E-MORB - Plume-MORB. N-MORB is depleted in trace elements compared to E-MORB.
references: Pearce, J.A. 2014. Immobile Element Fingerprinting of Ophiolites, Elements. vol. 10, pp. 101-108
Pearce, J.A. 2008. Geochemical fingerprinting of oceanic basalts with applications to ophiolite classification and the search for Archean oceanic crust, Lithos. vol. 100, pp. 14-48

diagrams.name: Basalt Th-Zr-Nb (Wood 1980)
comments: Basalt discrimination diagram based on HFS
Diagram is based on WOOD Th-Hf-Ta, 1980 but used when Hf and Ta are not analised but recalculated assuming a Zr/Hf ratio of 39 and a Nb/Ta ratio of 16
WPT within plate tholeiites, VAB volcanic arc basalts, IAT island arc tholeiites, CAB calk-alkaline basalts, WPB within plate basalts
references: Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 182-185.

diagrams.name: Basalt Ti vs V (Shervais 1982)
comments: Basalt classification using Ti/V ratios. Island-Arc Basalts/Tholeiites (IAB) plot between Ti/V ratios of 10 -20, Mid-Ocean Ridge Basalts (MORB) plot between Ti/V ratios of 20 -50 and Ocean Island & Alkali Basalts (OIB) plot between Ti/V ratios of 50 -100.
references: Shervais, 1982. Using Geochemical Data, by Hugh Rollinson, 1993. Page 186

diagrams.name: Basalt Ti vs Zr (Pearce and Cann 1973)
comments: Basalt discrimination diagram, IAT = island arc tholeiites, "Mix" field contains MORB, calc-alkali and island-arc tholeiites , MORB = Mid-Oceanic Ridge Basalts
references: Pearce and Cann, 1973 in Rollinson, Using Geochemical Data, 1993 p.177

diagrams.name: Basalt Ti-Zr-Sr (Pearce and Cann 1973)
comments: Discrimination diagram for basalts. Island-Arc tholeiites plot in field A, calc-alkaline basalts in field B and MORB plot in field C.
references: after Pearce and Cann, 1973 in Rollinson, Using Geochemical Data, 1993 p.178

diagrams.name: Basalt Ti-Zr-Y (Pearce and Cann 1973)
comments: Discrimination diagram for basalts. IAT = island-arc tholeiites, CAB = calc-alkaline basalts, MORB = mid-oceanic ridge basalts, WPB = within-plate basalts
references: Pearce and Cann, 1973 in Rollinson, Using Geochemical Data, 1993 p.176

diagrams.name: Basalt TiO2/Yb vs Nb/Yb (Pearce 2008)
comments: Fig 2b. Uses Ti-Yb as proxy for shallow and deep melting, reflected in the plot being classified into two distinct OIB and MORB arrays.
Th = Tholeiite, Alk = Alkali. MORB - Mid-Oceanic Ridge Basalt, OIB - Ocean-Island Basalt, N-MORB - Normal-MORB, E-MORB - Plume-MORB. N-MORB is depleted in trace elements compared to E-MORB.
references: Pearce, J.A. 2008. Geochemical fingerprinting of oceanic basalts with applications to ophiolite classification and the search for Archean oceanic crust, Lithos. vol. 100, pp. 14-48

diagrams.name: Basalt Zr-Nb-Y (Meschede 1986)
comments: Basalt discrimination diagram. Acronyms are within plate alkali basalts (WPAB), within plate tholeiites (WPT), volcanic arc basalts (VAB)
references: Meschede, 1986 in Rollinson, Using Geochemical Data, 1993 p.203

diagrams.name: Felsic Volcanic Fertility Plot La/Yb vs Yb (Hart et al 2004)
comments: Chondrite-normalised (cn) plot showing classification fields for felsic volcanic rock groups associated with VMS deposits. Axes are normalised to Yb and La values in Nakamura, 1974.
Diagram is divided into several fields for classifying felsic volcanic rocks based on petrogenetic models and tectonic environments: FI, FII, FIIIa, FIIIb and FIV.

FI and FII represents dacite-rhyolite rocks with alkaline-calc-alkaline affinity. FIIIa and FIIIb represents rhyodacite-high silica rhyolite with tholeiitic affinity. FIV represents high silica rhyolite with tholeiitic affinity.
references: Hart et al., 2004 Trace Element Geochemistry and Petrogenesis of Felsic Volcanic Rocks Associated With Volcanogenic Massive Cu-Zn-Pb Sulfide Deposits. Economic Geology, Vol. 99, pp. 1003-1013
Normalisation values are from Nakamura, 1974; Determination of REE, Ba, Mg, Na and K in carbonaceous and ordinary chondrites, Geochim. Cosmochim. Acta. vol. 38, pp. 757-775.
diagrams.sourceFile: Felsic Volcanic Fertility Plot La-Yb vs Yb (Hart et al, 2004).xml

diagrams.name: Th-Co Discrimination Diagram (Hastie et al 2007)
comments: Discrimination diagram for classifying altered volcanic island arc rocks. Classification field boundaries were constructed using composition data from island arc lavas.

Th and Co on y- and x-axes are used as proxies for K2O and SiO2 respectively. Th is used to subdivide volcanic arc rocks into volcanic series: tholeiitic, calc-alkaline, high-K calc-alkaline and shoshonitic.

Gradual removal of Co from the melt during crystallization of volcanic island arc rocks reflects fractionation from basalt to rhyolite, as shown in the field boundaries for the different rock types along the x-axis.
references: Hastie, A.R., Kerr, A.C., Pearce, J.A., Mitchell, S.F., 2007, Classification of Altered Volcanic Island Arc Rocks using Immobile Trace Elements: Development of the Th-Co Discrimination Diagram.  Journal of Petrology, v. 48, p. 2341-2357.

diagrams.name: Volcanic Rocks Classification (Stanley 2017)

SiO2 axis used to assign names to melts. Boundaries along  SiO2 axis loosely defined on Le Maitre et al. (1989) diagram and polygons named with -LeM suffix.
references: Stanley, C.R. 2017. Molar Element Ratio Analysis of Lithogeochemical Data: A Toolbox for Use in Mineral Exploration and Mining, Exploration 17: Integrating the Geosciences: the Challenge of Discovery. Decennial Mineral Exploration Conference. Toronto, Oct. Paper 33, pp. 471-494.

diagrams.name: Cl-Li-B Ternary Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Ternary of chloride, lithium and boron presented in Giggenbach (1991a) used to distinguish
geothermal waters from different sources, reveal fractionation associated with boiling/mixing
with boiled fluids,  or from absorption of high temperature stream from different sources.
See plot Tclb in the Powell and Cumming (2010) paper.
references: Powell, T., and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F., (1991a), "Chemical techniques in geothermal exploration,"
in UNITAR/UNDP Guidebook: Application of geochemistry in resources development, 119-144.

diagrams.name: Cl-SO4-HCO3 Ternary Anion Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Displays the proportions of the major anions present in geothermal water based on Giggenbach (1991a).
Plot labels indicate associations with different parts of a geothermal system or different types thereof.
Ternary plot Tcsh (FIgure 1) in Powell and Cumming (2010) paper.
references: Powell, T. and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F., (1991a), "Chemical techniques in geothermal exploration,"
in UNITAR/UNDP Guidebook: Application of geochemistry in resources development, 119-144.

diagrams.name: K-Mg and K-Ca Geothermometer Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Giggenbach and Goguel (1989) "geoindicator" plot showing K-Mg geothermometer and dissolved Ca and K.
Additional Y axis for measure of partial CO2 pressure not shown.
See plot Xkmc in the Powell and Cumming (2010) paper - note: y-axis is vertically inverted.
references: Powell, T., and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F. and Goguel, R.L (1989) "Collection and analysis of geothermal and volcanic water and gas discharges,"
DSIR report CD 2401, 4th ed., Pentone, New Zealand.

diagrams.name: K-Mg and Quartz Geothermometer Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Cross-plot of K-Mg geothermometer and quartz (conductive) geothermometer from Giggenbach and Goguel (1989).
Uses chalcedony geothermometer instead of quartz for water from a lower temperature source.
See plot Xkms in the Powell and Cumming (2010) paper - note: y-axis is vertically inverted.
references: Powell, T., and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F. and Goguel, R.L (1989) "Collection and analysis of geothermal and volcanic water and gas discharges,"
DSIR report CD 2401, 4th ed., Pentone, New Zealand.

diagrams.name: Na-K/Mg-Ca Geoindicator Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Giggenbach and Goguel (1989) "geoindicator" plot, an elaboration of the Na-K-Mg plot.
Displays the Na-K geothermometer with equilibrium of the system Mg-Ca.
Used to determine the influence of shallow, low temperature processes, which have
particular influence on the apparent Mg-Ca equilibrium. Appropriate for reservoirs
in carbonate rocks or fluids dominated by rock chemistry rather than geothermal equilibration.
See Xmckn in the Powell and Cumming (2010) paper.
references: Powell, T., and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F. and Goguel, R.L (1989) "Collection and analysis of geothermal and volcanic water and gas discharges,"
DSIR report CD 2401, 4th ed., Pentone, New Zealand.

diagrams.name: Na-K-Mg Geothermometer Plot
comments: Input variables in ppm.
Combines the Na-K geothermometer with the K-Mg geothermometer.
Similar to Giggenbach (1991a) "geoindicator" plot showing evidence supporting the
interpretation of equilibrated water at high temperature and the influence
of shallow processes and possible equilibration at lower temperature.
See ternary plot Tnkm (Figure 3) in the Powell and Cumming (2010) paper.
references: Powell, T., and Cumming, W., 2010, Spreadsheets for geothermal water and gas geochemistry,
Proceedings: Thirty Fifth Workshop on Geothermal Reservoir Engineering, Stanford University, California.
Giggenbach, W.F., (1991a), "Chemical techniques in geothermal exploration,"
in UNITAR/UNDP Guidebook: Application of geochemistry in resources development, 119-144.
